particulars: First European voyage to India. Four ships departed Lisbon; reached Calicut on 20 May 1498 after 10 months at sea. Opened the sea route to the East via the Cape of Good Hope.
Accompanied Sao Gabriel in Gama's first fleet. Burned on the return voyage near Mombasa due to insufficient crew to man all ships.
Smallest vessel in Gama's fleet. First ship to return to Lisbon, arriving 10 July 1499, confirming the discovery of the sea route.
Second India fleet with 13 ships. Accidentally discovered Brazil on 22 April 1500 while swinging wide in the Atlantic. Lost 4 ships rounding the Cape including Bartolomeu Dias's vessel.
Part of Cabral's fleet. One of the surviving vessels that reached India and returned laden with spices.
Lost rounding the Cape of Good Hope in one of the worst storms encountered by the early Portuguese fleets. All hands lost.
Disappeared in the Atlantic, presumably lost in a storm. Bartolomeu Dias also perished in this same fleet.
Third India fleet of 4 ships. Discovered Ascension Island on the outward voyage and Saint Helena on the return.
Part of Gama's second voyage with 20 ships. This massive carrack would later become the richest shipwreck in history when lost in 1511.
Gama's flagship on his second voyage. 20-ship fleet established Portuguese dominance by force, bombarding Calicut.
Albuquerque's first voyage to India. Three ships. Built Fort Cochin, the first European fort in India.
Large fleet of 13 ships. Reinforced Portuguese positions in India.
Almeida's fleet as first Viceroy of India. 22 ships with 1,500 soldiers. Established permanent Portuguese government in the East.
Part of Almeida's viceregal fleet. Helped establish fortified Portuguese trading posts along the East African coast.
Tristao da Cunha's fleet. Discovered the island group that bears his name (Tristan da Cunha) in the South Atlantic.
Albuquerque sailed in Tristao da Cunha's fleet but with his own squadron. Would soon become the greatest Portuguese governor.
Albuquerque's campaign to seize Hormuz at the entrance to the Persian Gulf. The Flor de la Mar served as flagship.
Fleet commander's ship lost in a storm near Mozambique. Aguiar drowned with most of the crew.
First Portuguese expedition to Malacca. Arrived in September 1509 but were attacked and had to flee. Set the stage for Albuquerque's later conquest.
After conquering Goa (November 1510), Albuquerque prepared for the Malacca campaign. The Flor de la Mar was already old and leaking.

After conquering Malacca, Albuquerque loaded the Flor de la Mar with the treasure of the Sultan of Malacca. Wrecked in a storm off Sumatra. Possibly the richest shipwreck ever -- its cargo may have included 60 tons of gold.
Post-Malacca conquest reinforcement fleet.
Sent to reinforce Goa and the Moluccas (Spice Islands).
Albergaria's viceregal fleet. He succeeded Albuquerque as Governor of Portuguese India.
Sequeira's governor fleet. Established diplomatic relations with China and sent Fernao Pires de Andrade to Canton.
Meneses served as Governor until 1524.
Gama's third and final voyage to India as Viceroy. He died in Cochin on 24 December 1524, just months after arrival.
Cunha's viceregal fleet. He would govern for 9 years, the longest tenure, and captured Diu in 1535.
Noronha succeeded Cunha as Viceroy. Large fleet to counter Ottoman expansion in the Indian Ocean.
Sousa's gubernatorial fleet. Strengthened Portuguese presence in India and Ceylon.
Castro's viceregal fleet. He is considered one of the greatest Portuguese viceroys, winning the Second Siege of Diu (1546).
Outward voyage completed. The Sao Bento would be wrecked on the return voyage in 1554, inspiring the Tragic History of the Sea.
Outward voyage to India. The Sao Joao would become one of the most famous Portuguese shipwrecks on the return in 1552.
Wrecked on the Natal coast, South Africa, on 11 June 1552. One of the most famous Portuguese shipwrecks, central to the Historia Tragico-Maritima. Sepulveda, his wife Leonor, and children perished.
Wrecked on the Natal coast near the Msikaba River in April 1554. Another famous wreck in the Historia Tragico-Maritima. Survivors marched overland for months.
Braganza's viceregal fleet. Period of consolidation in India.
Wrecked on a reef off the coast of Sumatra. Survivors spent weeks building a boat from the wreckage. One of the great survival stories.
Coutinho served as Viceroy during a period of growing Dutch menace.
Routine India voyage during the height of Portuguese trade.
Noronha's viceregal fleet.
Year of the Battle of Lepanto. Portuguese Asia largely unaffected.
Barreto's governorship period.
Large carrack. The Chagas would later be lost spectacularly in 1594.
Year King Sebastian died at Alcacer Quibir, triggering succession crisis.
Union of Crowns (1580): Portugal now under Spanish Habsburg rule. Portuguese India continued operating semi-independently.
Under Spanish rule. The India fleets continued but faced growing competition from English and Dutch interlopers.
Coutinho was also a famous Portuguese poet (Frei Luis de Sousa).
Wrecked on the Natal coast in 1593 on the return voyage. Yet another tragic shipwreck on the South African coast.
Albuquerque's viceregal fleet. Portuguese dealing with English and Dutch raids.

Enormous 1,600-ton carrack captured by the English off the Azores in August 1592. Her rich cargo of spices, silks, gold, and jewels sparked English interest in the India trade and inspired the founding of the EIC.
Enormous 2,000-ton carrack. Attacked by English raiders near the Azores. Caught fire during the battle and exploded. Over 600 killed, including many civilian passengers.
Last years of the 16th century. Dutch expeditions to the East beginning (Houtman's fleet sailed in 1596).
Year the English EIC was chartered (31 December 1600). Portuguese monopoly under threat.
Wrecked near Lisbon at the mouth of the Tagus (Sao Juliao da Barra) in September 1606. So close to home yet lost. Pepper cargo lost.
Dutch VOC now firmly established in the East. Portuguese losing trading posts.
Viceregal fleet. Year of the Twelve Years' Truce between Spain and the Dutch Republic (1609-1621).
Truce period. Portuguese fortresses in the East increasingly isolated as Dutch expanded.
Dwindling India fleet. Fewer and fewer ships dispatched annually.
Portuguese Estado da India under pressure from all sides: Dutch, English, and local powers.
Gama family descendant as Viceroy. Dutch captured Hormuz in 1622 with English help.
Lost in a storm off the coast of Mozambique. Dutch capturing more Portuguese positions.
Wrecked near the coast of Natal. Survivors endured a harrowing overland march. Account published in the Historia Tragico-Maritima.
Lost off the Cape coast. Portuguese India fleets increasingly reduced to a handful of ships.
Year of Portuguese Restoration: on 1 December 1640, Portugal regained independence from Spain under King Joao IV.
Post-Restoration. Portuguese rebuilding their eastern empire while fighting the Dutch.
Dutch captured Colombo (1656) during this period, ending Portuguese control of Ceylon.
Portuguese lost Cochin and Cannanore to the Dutch in 1663. The Estado da India reduced to Goa, Daman, and Diu.
Major warship-carrack. Lost near Mozambique Island on 26 June 1668. Carried a significant cargo.
Smaller fleets now, typically 1-3 ships per year.
Tavora's viceregal fleet. Portuguese India now a minor power.
Late 17th century. Portuguese India trade much reduced.
End of the 17th century. The Carreira continued but as a shadow of its former glory.
Only 1-2 ships now sailing the Carreira annually.
War of Spanish Succession (1701-1714) disrupted shipping. Portuguese siding with England.
Pombaline reforms would soon transform Portuguese trade.
Continuing annual (sometimes biannual) India voyages.
Saldanha's viceregal fleet. Portuguese rebuilding Goa trade.
Marques de Alorna's fleet. Period of Maratha wars.
Pombal era beginning. Reforms would reshape Portuguese trade.
Continuing the reduced Carreira. Typically 1-2 ships per year.
Lost in the Great Lisbon Earthquake aftermath period. Ships damaged by the tsunami of 1 November 1755 that devastated Lisbon.
Seven Years' War period (1756-1763). Portuguese neutral but affected.
Pombaline reforms: restructured monopoly companies for trade.
Late Pombal era. Trade partially revived through reforms.
End of the Pombaline era (Pombal fell from power in 1777).
Maria I succeeded Joseph I. End of Pombal's monopoly companies.
American Revolutionary War affecting Atlantic shipping.
Post-American independence. Trade routes stabilizing.
Continued annual Goa trade. Ships now much smaller.

ship_name: Nossa Senhora da Penha de Franca
particulars: Year of the French Revolution. Major geopolitical upheaval approaching.
French Revolutionary Wars beginning. Sea routes increasingly dangerous.
Wrecked off Peniche on the Portuguese coast. Significant cargo lost.
War of the First Coalition. British navy controlling sea lanes.
Lost off the Cape of Good Hope. British and French competing for control of the Cape route.
Napoleon in power. Portuguese alliance with Britain critical.
Peace of Amiens (1802-1803). Brief respite from warfare.
Napoleonic Wars resumed. Trafalgar approaching (1805).
Captured by a French privateer in the Atlantic during the Napoleonic Wars.
Portuguese court fled to Brazil in November 1807. India fleets now sailed from Rio de Janeiro instead of Lisbon.
Ships now departing from Brazil. Peninsular War raging in Portugal.
Napoleon's Russia campaign (1812). Portuguese India trade minimal.
Post-Napoleon. Lisbon resuming as departure port. Congress of Vienna.
Post-war Carreira. Very few ships now, mostly official transport.
Joao VI proclaimed king. Portuguese colonial empire restructuring.
Year of the Liberal Revolution in Portugal (1820).
Brazilian independence (7 September 1822). Portugal losing its largest colony.
Post-Brazilian independence. India now Portugal's most important remaining overseas territory.
Death of Joao VI (1826). Succession crisis between Pedro IV and Miguel.
Miguelite Wars (1828-1834). Civil war in Portugal.
Final years of the Carreira. Steamships beginning to appear.
Liberal Wars. Pedro IV's forces besieging Porto.
Convention of Evora-Monte (May 1834) ended the civil war. Liberal Portugal.
One of the last Carreira da India sailings. The era of regular sailing fleets to India was ending.
Enormous carrack. Lost in a storm near the Azores. She was one of the largest ships afloat at the time.
Captured by the Dutch near Saint Helena. One of the early Dutch seizures of Portuguese India ships.
Successful return voyage laden with pepper and cinnamon.
Part of Cunha's extended governorship. Capture of Diu (1535).

ship_name: Nossa Senhora do Monte do Carmo
particulars: Post-Restoration voyage. Portuguese rebuilding eastern trade.
Marques de Alorna era. Maratha conflicts.
Brief Peace of Amiens. One of the last calm India voyages before the Napoleonic Wars intensified.
